item.title: How Do You Balance Your Music
item.dc:creator: Sunny
item.description:
Freetime. Pick 1:

  • Make music on Auxy
  • Watch TV/Netflix/Youtube
  • Browse mindlessly on social media
  • Sport/Hobby/Recreation
  • Have a social life that involves seeing your close (also busy) friends more than once a month
  • Take care of your pets/children/dependants entertainment and needs properly.

Read full topic
item.source: How Do You Balance Your Music

item.title: How Do You Balance Your Music
item.dc:creator: Arimyth
item.description:
You have to think about it in terms of what you can control.

You canâ€™t control the important, pressing things you have to do in your life. For some it may be a job, for some it may be academics, for some it may family life.

The key thing to focus on is those chunks of time that you have input into. That hour you spend watching youtube or playing video gamesâ€“consider replacing a section of it (or the whole chunk of time) with music production instead.

Some peopleâ€™s lives may genuinely be too busy for music production to have a spot in it, but for most of us here, a little rearranging of some of the leisure activities we never took into account should do the trick.

Read full topic

item.title: How Do You Balance Your Music
item.dc:creator: iammane
item.description:
I was tempted to close this, but, itâ€™s tangentially related to production. I think this is a legit life question.

It just comes down to prioritization, and timing. I work on music usually on my commute. I work 9 hours a day and commute 4 (so 13 hours per day during the week). Iâ€™ve got two young kids at home (2 and 6) so the weekends are just go time with them. At night I like to just relax after the day is done, so I donâ€™t do any work during the night either.

The important thing is to prioritize - donâ€™t neglect things that are really important (family, work, etc) - perhaps shift time from activities that arenâ€™t as important to production (ie, I spent a lot of time playing computer and consoles games and never really do that anymore, that time was re-allocated to music).

Anyways, just my two pence. Weâ€™re just lucky we have these mobile devices to do this stuff because if we didnâ€™t, just straight up wouldnâ€™t have time to work on music.

Read full topic
